  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-31734].
  {panel}

If an user watches some pages, the change email is sent from: "User Name (Confluence) <admin@...>". If this user replies to the sent email, he sends his response to the site administrator instead of the original user.

It would be better if a "reply-to" header where added.
Just bring this feature in line with the "share" feature where the reply-to header works well.

In case of the "changes in the last 24h" might be improved with an additional "anonymous reply-to" configuration field. (But this special case is not as important, because users dont expect that replying to "anonymous" would be received by someone.)

fields.description:
I am trying to share the following link on a confluence page:

http://www.adaptavist.com/display/ADAPTAVIST/2011/12/07/5+Best+Practice+Tips+to+Improve+Search+in+Atlassian's+Confluence+Wiki

No matter what I try, the link doesn't work. I inspected the "a" element in chrome and found that here isn't an "href" element. I'm not sure if it has something to do with the link itself (perhaps the ' in Atlassian's) or something else.

Steps to reproduce (there are three different ways):

1. Copy the URL from the Chrome toolbar into the clipboard
2. Paste the link directly into a Confluence page
3. Save the Confluence page
4. When viewing the page, clicking on the link does nothing

Also...

1. Copy the URL from the Chrome toolbar into the clipboard
2. With a blank Confluence page, use the "link" button (or Ctrl+K) in the Page editor
3. Select "Web Link"
4. Paste the URL into the "Address" field
5. Save the Page
6. When viewing the Page, clicking on the link doesn't do anything

Also...

1. Use the "Share a Link" page blueprint
2. Paste the URL into the "Link" field
3. The title isn't automatically retreived by Confluence (like it does with other links)
4. Saving the Page
5. When viewing the Page, clicking on the link doesn't do anything

I am using Chrome 31
fields.summary: Sharing a link doesn't create the "href" element for the "a" tag

fields.description:
SUMMARY
Confluence: Adding a check mark before a hyper link would fail silently.
STEPS TO REPRODUCE
1. Edit a page.
2. Insert a link to another page on a new line, then save.
3. Edit the page again and move the cursor to just before the link, then insert emoticon. See attached screenshot 1. Save.
RESULTS
After save, the checkmark does not show up. See attached screenshot 2.
WORKAROUND
1. Insert a space after the emoticon (before the hyperlink) and then click save. Then the emoticon stays. 
2. Edit the page again and delete the space you added in step 1. Then save. Then the emoticon stays again whereas before it vanished.

Additional testing has show that emoticons can not be part of the title of a link. When inserting one directly next to a link in edit mode, the emoticon gets rendered (ie {code}(/){code} for check mark).
Upon saving the page, the emoticon will disappear. 
When clicking on the link in edit mode, navigate to the edit option of the link and adding the ( / ) to the title there, the short cut for the emoticon will not get rendered after page save, and the title of the link will simply display the 3 characters ( / )

In effect this appears to relate to CONF-26042

Besides that, another additional testing on Confluence 5.4.4 shows that this issue cannot be replicated if the link inserted to the page is a web link.
fields.summary: Emoticons disappear when inserted directly before a link

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#FFFFCE}
This issue exists solely for documentary purposes of an Oracle/OpenJDK JVM bug Confluence's code (i.e. [View File Macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/View+File+Macro]) might be able to provoke. Causing this bug will lead to a JVM crash originating in the {{\[libpthread.so.0+0xe242\]  sem_post+0x12}} frame.

*The issue will be fixed in an upcoming Java release. See below for details.*
{panel}

Requests to the PPTSlideServlet ([View File Macro|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/View+File+Macro]) can cause the JVM to crash. The problem is described [here|https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-6935062?focusedCommentId=12079957&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-12079957] and the main bug report is [JDK-8009402|https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8009402].

I was able to reproduce the problem on the 7u25 and 7u45 JVMs, and it appears to be fixed on 8b115. It will also be fixed in the upcoming [7u51|https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8026896] and [7u60|https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8026521] releases.

According to [a mail|http://www.mail-archive.com/jdk7u-dev@openjdk.java.net/msg07795.html] on the [jdk7u-dev|http://mail.openjdk.java.net/mailman/listinfo/jdk7u-dev], those releases should be expected early next year.

{quote}
With 7u51 and 7u55 being planned as the January 2014 and April 2014 JDK releases, it makes sense for 7u60 to be released some time after April 2014. The current proposal is that 7u60 will GA in May 2014.
{quote}

Below are the tests performed with the [SemPostCrash.zip|https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/secure/attachment/16547/SemPostCrash.zip] program.

uname -a

fields.description:
In-place upgrades of Confluence Clustered installations doesn't work, and hasn't worked since Confluence 5.1.2.

To reproduce:

# Setup 2 nodes of a Confluence 5.0.x clustered installation
# Shutdown the nodes
# Upgrade node 1 to Confluence 5.4, verify that the database is upgraded as expected
# Upgrade node 2 also, note that startup fails due to "the build number in the home directory \[4109\] doesn't match the build number in the database \[4723\]" 

Upgrading cluster installations to any version prior to 5.1.2 works fine, but upgrading any cluster installations to 5.1.2 or later will likely fail.

Importantly, this *only* affects Confluence clustered installations, and only those being upgraded from one version to another using in-place upgrades rather than site imports.
fields.summary: BootstrapManager blocks in-place upgrades for cluster installations

fields.description:
When a confluence page (v4.x) is edited and saved in IE with Lync or Skype plugin enabled, the diff highlights phone #s blue as if they were changed (when they clearly have not been changed).

Viewing the source shows that Lync plugin has inserted a <SPAN CLASS> tag and <A TITLE="Call: ###-###-####"> and it gets *saved* as if the user made this change. Skype does something else but I think it is the same issue. See attached screen caps to see how Lync inserts markup and what diff detects.

This makes diffing very difficult since you can't determine if a phone number has changed between versions whenever someone with browser plugin that injects code or hijacks phone numbers edits a confluence page.
fields.summary: Confluence diff detects changes in phone numbers when page edited in IE (Lync plugin)

fields.description:
Due to Spring's lazy initialisation, it's possible for some plugin components to never be instantiated. Specifically, a bean which implements {{InitializingBean}} that is not explicitly referenced elsewhere in the application will never be created.

This can happen when a {{<component>}} is being used for event listening. As the bean would normally register itself with an event publisher on init (and will only ever be referenced by that event publisher in the future) it will never actually be instantiated.

The plugin enable process should be modified to ensure that at least one call to getBean is done.

LEGACY: https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/CONF/repos/confluence/pull-requests/2001/overview
PR: https://stash.atlassian.com/projects/CONF/repos/confluence/pull-requests/7465/overview
BV: https://collaboration-bamboo.internal.atlassian.com/branchinator/13041798/confluence_master%20(read-only)/issue%252FCONF-31670-EWD
fields.summary: Plugin components that implement InitializingBean are sometimes not instantiated

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-31664].
  {panel}

I work in a distributed team that extensively uses Confluence wiki. So keep myself up-to-date I'm "watching" pages, also i have an "rss" set up to chow changes made to pages tagged by a specific label.

"Watching" pages is nice, because you get diff of a page's before/after state, which RSS doesn't provide (because of https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-26109, which I consider an odd decision, a kind of reluctance, and in current state it is a real issue to guess what has been added/changed/removed by looking at a message in RSS without a walk in browser; a side thought: then at least would be nice to have a configuration option in RSS builder to switch off showing of a content in RSS messages to keep RSS posts concise as all-in-all they do not provide info i'm looking for).

However "watching" pages itself is not perfect too. Because people create new pages here and there, and it is not possible to watch a page along with its child pages (besides, sometimes pages of interest just cannot be organized in a parent-child page structure in a natural way). At the same time it is relatively easy to train everyone in a team to use a set of tags. But again, Confluence has no way to "watch" changes made to a tagged content. Would be nice to have that.

And, finally, there is another problem with "watching" for changes in pages:   frequently people do not make all changes to a page in a single edit. So they edit a bit, then look and remember something and edit again, or update content during a day until it is stabilized and etc. And in turn I get a couple of emails related to a single change. I wish i cold receive only one notification in this case, e.g. send a notification for a particular page only after some quiet time. Alternatively i can imagine an option to switch to a periodic (e.g. daily) receiving of "page-watching" notifications, with automatic merging of a changes made by a single person to a single page.

What do you think about all that?
fields.summary: Watch tagged pages and optionally summarize notifications during a day

fields.description:
h4. Symptoms

In the JIRA Issues Macro documentation, it says that you can use Basic Access application link authentication, so that the issues that get displayed are those that the user in the application link has access to. This is no longer working, the only issues that can be viewed by an anonymous user, for example, are the ones that are viewable by an anonymous user in JIRA.

Whilst this makes logical sense from a security standpoint, our [documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/JIRA+Issues+Macro] explicitly says that you should be able to see any issues that the Basic Access user can see. This was also working in older versions of Confluence/JIRA Issues Macro.

h4. Steps to Reproduce

# Create an application link between JIRA and Confluence using Basic Access
# Create a page in Confluence, and add some JIRA issues
# Make sure that page is anonymously accessible and the JIRA issues are not anonymously accessible
# Load that page as anonymous (e.g. in incognito mode) and see that no issues are listed if it should be a table, or that only the issue key and no other details are showing if a single issue.
fields.summary: JIRA Issues Macro does not work using Basic Access application link as described in documentation

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-31662].
  {panel}

Hi Atlassian, 

i have a translation issue here. The translation for "watching" pages is wrong in a very particular way, The german word "überwachen" has many very bad connotations. The meaning is more like "observing" or "supervising". This makes every german user i encounter react, on one hand because of the actual NSA discussion, on the other hand because of german history. Surveillance made a lot of dark chapters in german history, the last not long ago in GDR before 1990. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stasi for ex. 

I am not that captious normally, but in that case i'd really wish that you could change the wording. There are two options that would do better: "abonnieren" oder "beobachten", whereas "abonnieren" is the more factual alternative with a meaning more like "subscribe". This would do best in my opinion. I added translations for all the occurrences of the word "überwachen" to "abonnieren" here: https://translations.atlassian.com/dashboard/translate#/48/5085/0/ACCEPTED_TRANSLATIONS/ALL/%C3%BCberwachen

Best wishes

Matin
fields.summary: German translation for "watching"

Please note that a server restart solves the issue and we can use our plugin.

We found a old bug that was fixed, it might be related though... - https://ecosystem.atlassian.net/browse/PLUG-199

fields.description:
If we are using a small or narrow monitor, the tool tips box can cover important links on the scheduled jobs page of the administrative screens.  For an example, please see the attached screen shot.

*Steps to reproduce*
# Navigate to Confluence admin -> scheduled jobs
# Adjust the width of the browser to be narrower until the tool tips being to go over other text on the page

*Workaround*
Expand the width of the browser

This occurs in Chrome Version 30.0.1599.101 as well as Safari Version 6.0.5 (8536.30.1).  Also, this issue was identified and marked resolved in earlier versions of Confluence but appears to have returned so I have created this new report which links to the original reports as well.
fields.summary: Help Tips Cover Important Links on 'Scheduled Jobs' page

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up Confluence 5.3 and JIRA 6.1
# Create an application link from Confluence to JIRA and a reciprocal link
# Update all plugins in Confluence (see application.xml in attached Support Zip for my current versions)
# Check Software Blueprints is on version 2.3.2
# Create a JIRA Status Report Blueprint and save it
# Observe the errors in the page, as per the screenshot.

h3. Fix
This issue is caused by a JIRA problem [JRA-34911|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRA-34911], which was resolved in JIRA 6.1.1. Please upgrade JIRA to 6.1.1 or above to resolve this issue.

NB: If you are experiencing this with anonymous users, this is a different issue. Please see [CONF-31983|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-31983] for more information.
fields.summary: JIRA Status Report Blueprint - 'Unable to render JIRA chart macro, due to an execution error.'

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up JIRA 6.1  with a project, and Confluence 5.3
# Create an applink between the two, from JIRA, then reciprocal from Confluence
# Hit Create > JIRA Report
# Select either report
# Note that you cannot select a Project, despite there being an available project

I believe this is because the 'Log in & Approve' dance hasn't been performed at this stage, however the user is not prompted to perform it.

NB: I cannot even add a JIRA Issues Macro to a page to be promtped for the dance - I simply get 'The JIRA server didn't understand your search query.'

h3. Cause
This occurs because you hit this bug when setting up the Application Links, and the link was not completely configured:
https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-31635

h3. Workaround
Remove the application link entirely. Recreate it, starting from Confluence, and allow the link to be completely created.
Now, when you go to create a Report, you will be prompted to Log in & Approve.
fields.summary: JIRA Report Macros do not show any projects when app link is initally set up

fields.description:
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set up JIRA 76.1 and Confluence 5.3
# Create an applink from JIRA to Confluence
# Specify you are an admin in both, to be redirected to Confluence
# When the redirect occurs, you go to a URL like this: 
_http://localhost:10530/admin/listapplicationlinks.action?applinkCreationStatusLog=%22\[\{\%22status\%22:\%22inprogress.creation\%22},\{\%22status\%22:\%22completed.creation.local\%22},\{\%22status\%22:\%22inprogress.creation.reciprocal\%22}]%22_
# First, the URL is not populated automatically. 
#Second, you can never click 'Create new link' - it is always greyed out. There is a throbber next to it that never stops throbbing (see screenshot).
# Refreshing the page does not work

h3. Workaround
Remove the Application Link from JIRA completely. Start setting the Application Link up from Confluence directly, and allow it to redirect you to JIRA to create the reciprocal link.
fields.summary: Cannot create reciprocal Application Link when redirected from JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-31629].
  {panel}

In Confluence,  each user can disable/enable some of keyboard shortcuts with [this procedure|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Keyboard+Shortcuts#KeyboardShortcuts-Disablingandre-enablingkeyboardshortcuts].

But such like "Ctrl (Cmd) + Shift + J" which activates Japanese FEP in Mac OS is controlled by JIRA Macros", not by shortcut-plugin.  So user can't control this shortcut  "Ctrl (Cmd) +Shift +J" in above procedure. 
If user wants to disable "Ctrl (Cmd) + Shift +J",  user must disable or rebuild "JIRA Macro" and this impacts all user of Confluence.

It is very nice if each user can control all of keyboard shortcuts in Confluence.

Regards,
fields.summary: Enable the users to control the all of keyboard shortcuts in Confluence

fields.description:
We have identified and fixed a vulnerability in Confluence which allowed unauthenticated users to commit actions on behalf of any other authorised user. In order to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker requires access to Confluence web interface.

The vulnerability affects all supported versions of Confluence up to and including 5.4.

Versions 5.3.4, 5.4 and 5.4.1 are not vulnerable but require patches for compatibility purposes in order to be able to connect to patched or upgraded versions of JIRA and other Atlassian products. You do not need to patch these versions if you are not using Application Links with Trusted Applications authentication configured. Version 5.4.2 is not vulnerable but contains a bug [CONF-32397].

This issue has been fixed in 5.4.3.

For more information, see our [security advisory|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Confluence+Security+Advisory+2014-02-26].
fields.summary: Privilege escalation

fields.description:
This is from: JRA-34550
* It has been marked as fixed, but it seems that the problem is still occurring, see below

With Confluence running over HTTP and JIRA running over HTTPS (8443), the application link is created with a default OAuth authentication but the integration fails.

*Steps to Reproduce*

1. Install Confluence 5.3.1, configured over HTTP
2. Install Jira 6.1.3, configured over HTTPS with port 8443
3. Create application link within Confluence
4. Link is created, but Confluence says Jira is offline (screenshot _list_links_)
5. Add issues macro to Confluence page. With OAuth configured, login is required(screenshot _insert_jira_issue_). When you click Login an error is thrown (screenshot _login_). With Trusted Applications configured, searching for an issue to add throws a warning (screenshot _insert_jira_issue_ta_).

*It looks like the HTTPS port is still missing from the header.* 

When you create the application link there's a broken image on the _List applications_ dialog because the URL for fetching the image from JIRA is missing the port (screenshot _broken_image_).

h3. Workaround

Host JIRA behind a reverse-proxy, such as Apache using our recommended configuration:

* [Integrating JIRA with Apache using SSL|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Integrating+JIRA+with+Apache+using+SSL]

This will serve HTTPS on port 443 on Apache, however JIRA will be serving HTTP behind that proxy, effectively working around the problem. It is the recommendation of Atlassian Support to use this configuration over setting up HTTPS on Tomcat as the configuration of it is considered to be easier to achieve.

Alternatively, you can run JIRA directly on 443.

Another workaround is to add proxyName and proxyPort to JIRA's SSL connector, even if there's no proxy:

proxyName="JIRA server name"
proxyPort="JIRA SSL port (e.g. 8443)"
fields.summary: Confluence cannot connect to JIRA on non-standard HTTPS port

fields.description:
The tooltip for the tables dropdown does not follow the dropdown around appropriately, and can thus even keep the user from being able to click the dropdown to select the tablesize he wants

I wanted a 10-row table.

I clicked the table dropdown in the editor

I dragged down to 10 rows.  Toward the end a black tipsy tooltip about holding SHIFT appeared right over where my mouse was.  I could no longer click the table thumbnail in the dropdown in order to select my table.

I suffered .05 on the small annoyances scale.

It's not a big thing, but just slightly annoying.
